name: Kathy Mattea
description: '''Kathleen Alice Mattea''' (born June 21, 1959){{sfn|Whitburn|2012|p=210}} is an American [[country music]] and [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] singer. Active since 1984 as a recording artist, she has charted more than 30 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, including four that reached No. 1: "[[Goin' Gone]]", "[[Eighteen Wheels and a Dozen Roses]]", "[[Come from the Heart]]", and "[[Burnin' Old Memories]]", plus 12 more that charted within the top ten. She has released 14 studio albums, two Christmas albums, and one greatest hits album. Most of her material was recorded for [[Universal Music Group Nashville]]'s [[Mercury Records]] Nashville 8division between 1984 and 2000, with later albums being issued on [[Narada Productions]], her own Captain Potato label, and [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]. Among her albums, she has received five gold certifications and one platinum certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). She has collaborated with [[Dolly Parton]], [[Michael McDonald (singer)|Michael McDonald]], [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], and her husband, [[Jon Vezner]]. Mattea is also a two-time [[Grammy Award]] winner: in 1990 for "[[Where've You Been]]", and in 1993 for her Christmas album ''[[Good News (Kathy Mattea album)|Good News]]''. Her style is defined by traditional country, bluegrass, [[folk music|folk]], and [[Celtic music]] influences. She was inducted into the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 2025.
